threads.com:
/vrpg/ is a place to discuss all types of role-playing video games, including single-player, multi-player, and massively multi-player, turn-based and real-time action, western-style and JRPG.

Does this mean RPGs are banned on other video game boards? No! /vrpg/ is just a separate board specifically focused on RPGs where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vrpg/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/.

Hello
I thought I should make a thread here and I couldn't see any up for the original Fallout. I know it's probably too early in the game for me to really be asking advice but I'm getting kind of stuck. I went to Shady Sands, discovered they had a radscorpion problem, and went to the caves to try and help since I figured there might be something useful to get out of it and I figured I could get more familiar with the combat.
Only I'm getting trounced by these damn radscorpions. I've figured that combat should be me engaging from a distance, firing a shot with my pistol then retreating (since I only have enough AP for a single shot right now); only it seems very much a gamble whether I hit the scorpion enough times before they can close on me, and once they've done so I seem to be stuck either in a cycle of healing and getting attacked, or getting stung to death while I keep trying to shoot and run.
I feel like there's something I'm missing about the combat system that asking you guys might help with. Is there anything obvious? Did I make a mistake coming to this cave so quickly? (I've not been in any other fights apart from the ants in the starting cave, and since this is my second character I just ran past most of them rather than stick around to fight)
Any advice please would be much appreciated. Thank you.

threads.sub: why haven't 90% of the innovations made in this game become standards of the JRPG genre?
threads.com: the overworld encounters, autobattling, and rolling HP meter make it a way more engaging and streamlined experience. most jrpgs since then seem to be cut from the same cloth from the 80s or so. it's not like stealing the game mechanics is going to take away from earthbound itself, or that the series is going anywhere. game developers are willing to make the game worse just so they aren't copying something, like every game isn't in one way built off another game. i don't think the game is perfect, but i think other games could learn a lot from it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2862625
You're 1/3. The autobattling OP means is when an enemy significantly weaker than you, encounters with them get bypassed and you automatically defeat them. If you PLAYED earthbound you'd know that. You gave up on rolling HP. No reason other games can't use it just because the inspiration is clear. It's a fun mechanic.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2865576
>The autobattling OP means is when an enemy significantly weaker than you
Then he should've specified that, considering that's not what fucking autobattle means in terms of JRPGs. Even then there's a bunch of modern JRPGs that automatically make enemies you face that are weaker than you run away like in Earthbound or make it so you automatically defeat them/make them disappear.

>If you PLAYED earthbound you'd know that.
I've beaten the game twice you fucking retarded faggot.

>You gave up on rolling HP. No reason other games can't use it just because the inspiration is clear. It's a fun mechanic.
If you used half a braincell you'd realize why more games don't use it, because it makes combat too cheesable and makes it easier to never get punished for your mistakes. Mother 3 is overly forgiving with its rolling HP which basically makes it impossible to die mid/late-game, especially since Boney basically out-speeds everything so he can heal before any enemy gets the chance to attack. Even in Earthbound it's pretty easy to cheese since hitting auto-battle will make the AI instantly heal any mortally wounded party members so you don't have to worry about wasting time menu-crawling to do it. It's a gimmick at best and doesn't add much other than just making the game either, most modern JRPGs want to focus on making the combat very snappy where a single bad choice can fuck you over, and focus on other more in-depth mechanics that push the player to think about their choices in battle Rolling HP just invalidates a lot of that since it means late-game you can just tank shit and spam healing spells/items to win.

threads.sub: What is the correct mindset to enjoy DRPGs?
threads.com:
I've tried playing some DRPGs and there's a lot of things I like about them:
>party management
>free character creation, allowing for a multitude of approaches
>first person exploration is usually immersive
>I like drawing maps and making my own notes

Even though I like all these things, there's one thing that always filters me in these games: the combat. No matter how much I try, it seems that all the DRPGs really on two types of battles: the ones where you mash attack until the enemy is dead without worrying about anything and the ones where you try to mash attack to win but the enemy completely destroys your whole party with just one attack. This second option usually becomes a RNG fest, because while the enemy always has this attack that wipes your party, it can use it on turn 1, turn 10 or never use it, so it all comes down to luck.
So, what you do to enjoy this? Do you just accept that combat is shit and decide to have a good time with the remaining characteristics of the game?

threads.com:
Looting in warpigs:
>finish a battle
>individually search each and every enemy's corpse and click "take all" along with collecting random bits of cutlery and other garbage littering the room
>become overburdened with useless vendor trash that only exists to be sold
>spend the next few minutes figuring out how to most efficiently distribute the weight between your party, changing equipment to maximise strength bonuses as you do
>head to town to sell everything, making sure to give it all to the party member with the highest barter skill first
>go back to get the rest of the loot
>turns out the merchant doesn't have enough money to buy everything

Looting in jarpigs:
>finish battle
>results screen shows any items you automatically looted, which you can usually carry with effectively no limit
>that's it

Why is it still like this? I'm not even trying to go full weeb and say jarpigs are totally superior, there are definitely things warpigs do better but this isn't one of them. Seriously, why do encumbrance mechanics even still exist? They can't be for realism because they're usually generous enough to let you carry way more than you ever could in reality, and they aren't there as a strategic constraint on the amount of resources you can carry because consumables are typically light and make up maybe 20% of the total weight at most. I like inventory limits in survival horror and some other genres but in any RPG where looting is a major component of the gameplay they need to go, unless maybe the game is really trying hard to be at least somewhat realistic.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2856695
None of the things you posted about wrpgs are a bad thing.
>wrpgs trust you enough to allow you to choose whether or not you want to loot absolutely everything you find and provides mechanical incentives against doing so
>wrpgs are mechanically complex enough to let you design a dedicated trapper, lockpicker, negotiator, etc.
>wrpgs actually have skills for characters outside of combat
>jarpigs only have enough numbers to provide the illusion of playing an rpg and even then it's just a simplified wizardry combat simulator
>jarpigs have mostly incredibly simple mechanics so that they can be played by their target audience: young children
Meanwhile
>Seriously, why do encumbrance mechanics even still exist? They can't be for realism because they're usually generous enough to let you carry way more than you ever could in reality, and they aren't there as a strategic constraint on the amount of resources you can carry because consumables are typically light and make up maybe 20% of the total weight at most.
It depends on the game. Encumbrance mechanics exist because they were designed for games that emulate an adventure. That is, it is supposed to also aspects of an adventure like the total amount of equipment and resources need for an adventure. This is why D&D and other tabletop games had rations and other necessary equipment like tents, sleeping rolls, etc. you'd bring along on an adventure or having only enough room or carrying capacity on your cart/donkey to carry a limited amount of things. Part of an rpg is also supposed to be planning. Carrying capacity is an important aspect there.
>I like inventory limits in survival horror and some other genres but in any RPG where looting is a major component of the gameplay they need to go
No. The only problem here is that many rpg developers don't go far enough emulating the aspects of an adventure.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2856695
you have to remember clicking on a corpse is essentially a small moment of gambling. It's the same skinner box effect as lootboxes.
You don't know if you got something good before you do it, but there *might* be, and when you open up that inventory screen your brain's dopamine is going up. And the low chance and random patterns of it both work to increase this effect.
Now, jrpgs are set up to make this simple, they want you to go back into the main gameplay loop again, so while the gambling aspect of it is still there, they make it quick and combine it all together.
Western devs don't take it in that direction. They have found the skinner box works, and by making you go through each individual one not only are they increasing your overall playtime, but they're also making you go through that gambling motion significantly more times.
A big thing is that combat encounters in jrpgs are usually more frequent as well - they don't need the extra stimuli push after every single fight because there's likely going to be more lower stakes fights

Anyway, easiest fights are rising dead in the graveyard (because they move slow and as long as you keep eye on stamina there's always way to retreat and rest) and hobo ambush, the pitchfork mob that often tries to extort Lona first (because they are just weak), you can practice combat on those with relative ease until you get proper grip on how things work.
In the arena you can take advantage of the environment, obstacles are there for a reason (and most enemies won't have ranged attack), so you can maneuver and run around to always engage one enemy at the time. The biggest danger isn't getting hit but rather getting surrounded.
Learn to hunt boars, it will be useful when taking on the Beast of the arena.
Outside of the arena, hirelings are cheap, can do most of the work for you (at least in the early quests) and those not attached to a questline are completely expendable, so you can always abandon them the the enemy and run away if things turn south.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Daggerfall requires a lot of effort on the player to enjoy. A lot of suspension of disbelief. But if you allow yourself to be fooled, it is actually a very fun game. Even though every quest and city is procedurally generated, after you've been playing for a while you kind of allow the illusion that every location is unique to grow on you. You get a sense of scale and realism that no other RPG offers.

I remember Zaric saying that every region in Daggerfall felt unique to him. I thought this was nonsense. How could a region feel unique when it uses the exact same generation algorithm as every other generic region in the game? I didn't understand this until I properly played Daggerfall and gave it a chance rather than dismissing it as procedurally generated garbage like I had done before. For example, over time you remember certain town layouts, you find a city with all the right services that your character requires in the one place, or you grow fond of a city that you've done a lot of quests in. And after a while of helping people out you see your reputation in a region has grown, it feels good that your actions in this world actually mean something.

Daggerfall definitely has something that no other RPG I've played has. A sense of immersion that you really are just an itinerant adventurer living in a fantasy world. Even though it's from 1996 it feels surprisingly modern in the amount of freedom it gives you.

Of course, the Unity version and shit ton of mods help a lot too. There are a lot of quest and world overhaul mods so the game doesn't feel so samey all the time.

I'm going to give Skyrim another attempt after nearly 11 years--partly because I really need some light recreation in my free evenings that isn't going to be too engrossing, but mostly for research/academic purposes. I want to keep it as vanilla as I can without subjecting myself to the completely insufferable banality of the whole thing that was the base game all those year ago, so I bought the Anniversary Edition on GOG instead of fishing out my original 2011 disc from storage and will be intially adding the CC Survival Mode mod along with Camping and Backpacks to spice things up a bit, as well as disabling quest markers in the .ini and trying to muddle through with the "Clairvoyance" spell if necessary. I have no idea if this is viable, but I want to make a fair attempt at enjoying what is there to be enjoyed.

Does anyone here have any modifications to suggest that would compliment a vanilla, "research"-style playthrough? Good skin mods, or maybe a few quest mods that showcase community talent without being too disruptive? Are any of the unofficial patches completely necessary (I want to avoid them if possible)?

I've been meaning to give the game a proper playthrough for many years now despite being disgusted and disappointed when it first released, just as I did with Oblivion years and year ago--and I had much more fun the second time around with that game once I stopped comparing it to its predessor.

Just finished pic related.
Enjoyed it.
But i wish it had a higher budget, higher 3D model animation quality, more 2D animated cutscenes etc.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2863842
>FFX came out 1 year after IX
and it still managed to have a very high level of quality for its time with like 50+ CG cutscenes, full voice acting for cutscenes etc.

CG cutscenes were amazing back when graphics were more primitive. It was awesome seeing FF7 cutscenes because the characters looked detailed and proportional. The cutscenes showed you a representation of what the characters you have been playing actually look like. FFX cutscenes were good because they still looked better than the regular in-game models. Once you get to PS3 and beyond where graphics have improved to the point where all the cutscenes practically look very similar to the in-game graphics, the cutscenes start to feel more intrusive.

Even with current gen games I am playing for the first time I find myself just waiting for the cutscenes to be over so I can get control of my character again. I tried Chrono Cross for the first time this past year and loved every cutscene, so it isn't that I grew out cutscenes. It's just that they are more spectacular on the older games because of the contrast with the dated graphics.

As for you wanting them to reach a decent middle ground, something will always need to be sacrificed. In the case of Ys VIII, better animations and cutscenes would probably have come at the cost of a shorter game, less moves, smaller world, etc. If the budget for the game was $5 million, with $1 million on graphics and $4 million on gameplay and coding, to get what you want they would have had to allocate $3 million to graphics and $2 million to gameplay and coding. Ys is a pretty niche series that will never get a budget like Final Fantasy, but even with the lower budget I enjoyed it more than FF 12, 13, & 15.

For example, see >>2861757.
This is the Adventurer's Guild, long abandoned.
But if you're a mage you can read the books in the library to learn a new spell and improve your spellcasting skill, while other classes only get some info about the setting.
If you're a warrior you can pass a strength skillcheck to smash that case with the sword to upgrade your weapon, something only the warrior can do. You can also use those weighted balls on the ground to train and raise your strength.
The rogue is the best here, because if you picked that class you can unlock a secret puzzle near the bookshelf that reveals a hidden passageway behind that portrait above it that leads to a unique location with an npc rogue and more loot and stuff.
You can also use that grapple on the hook above it to improve the climbing skill.

This room alone has tons of secrets that vary depending on your class, and the rest of the game follows.

threads.com: this isn't about deus ex vs. fallout, just the inventory system. i like that with a grid you can see everything at once instead of scrolling through a list and having 5 different lists, but only having 30 different spaces means you can't carry a large variety of items. with a list, there can be lots of different things with very small weights, like ammo. each round has a low weight but it adds up realistically, so you can decide if you want to carry a variety of calibers or just a ton of ammo for one gun you like. in deus ex, you have absolute ammo limits like 150 10mm rounds. i know human revolution's grid has smaller spaces and more of them, which means ammo can be kept in the main inventory, but in that when you have a lot of ammo of one type it clutters your grid because it only stacks up to 50 rounds in a box so you'll have ten boxes of the same thing all over your inventory, so i like the deus ex 1 grid more. STALKER is a weird case because it's limited by weight but displays things on a grid with infinite spaces. i never liked that because you still carry a lot of different items like artifacts, ammo types, and every duplicate weapon still appears in a new space instead of ak-74 (x3) or something. so all that combined with items having images and everything being in one category means your inventory can be so visually cluttered you have to scroll way down to find something even if you're way under the weight limit. i don't hate it, it's just a little weird. it probably comes down to the complexity of the game. like i was saying, lists can do small objects and an infinite variety of things but for an action game the grid being simpler and faster to look through is better.

ER follows From's usual story line, which is that the world has gone to hell because of the mistakes of the past, and it is up to you to fix that. Like in Dark Souls, 'fixing it' may be either just put a band-aide / cast on it and keep things hobbling along, or breaking it entirely and starting anew. There's a bit of hope in that.

If you want real depression, play Bloodborne.

>>2863512
The core gameplay I quite enjoyed. The characterization of the core cast I thought was great, and the best parts of the remake were expanding on the background characters of AVALANCHE, more time with the core cast, and I also did enjoy helping the Don Corneo lacky. However for every positive gameplay expansion/addition I found there were more mediocre puzzles, not difficult but tedious to expand gameplay. Chapters added in that have little to no additional content aside from half a dozen character interactions to give a break from a tedious puzzle. Getting to sector 7, going into the sewers, climbing into midgear . most if not all the content in there is needless fluff, my problem isn't that it's different. my problem is that many of the additions lack depth, had mediocre rewards, and especially when the plot pick up feel really out of place. Expanding on the side quests they are either "hunt the thing" or "Look for these people" that are just filler and feel disconnected especially after the plate collapses. The Midgear section alone is too confining for being a 25ish hour game.

Sephiroth appearing was a terrible decision, he wasn't scary because he constantly appeared in the beginning but the fact that he was built up naturally over the first few hours, while added visions wouldn't have been terrible or cloud pausing in fear at a fire him full on appearing only serves as fanservice.
The fate ghosts are a horrible new thing added "fate" seems to intervene whenever the hell the plot demands wedge living, the entire underground lab mission, red 13/Marlene knowing the future, Sephiroth appearing before the party at all (also seem to have some weird deal with him), or when they injure Jesse something that explicitly didn't happen in the original. they are inconsistent and further really show the attitude the writers have. The fans that like the original and want the story to stay on that track are literal wraiths that hurt the characters that must be defeated. Bringing back Aerith with the knowledge of the original game undermines her death and further at the end really goes off the rails when she talks of "fighting against fate" and the party having no context simply agrees.
The story now isn't even a remake but a completely separate timeline or whatever bull they will pull, but people see the flashy new version with all the advent children references and will overlook how multiple aspects of the original are undermined by the game.

threads.sub: Pitch Ideas for RPGs Nobody But You Would Play
threads.com: You play a white shota adventuring through fantasy Africa with a party of female fantasy African women.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Game inspired by Victorian adventure novels and Méliès' A Trip to the Moon.
You're a precocious young child who stows away aboard a craft to be sent to Mars and accidentally launch it. When you get to Mars you are confronted by the Kingdom of Mars and are unable to communicate with them.
Some react with hostility, some with curiosity, and others with fear, but it can be hard to tell the difference because of the language barrier.
You can easily kill them with your umbrella because they are very weak of constitution compared to you, and you can make a beeline for their capital, kill their king, and proclaim yourself King of Mars. This can be done relatively easily, and by the end, Mars will be a colony of whatever nation you've chosen as your origin.
The other main option is to figure out how to communicate with them which will eventually lead you into an existing narrative involving the kingdom's politics and domestic & foreign issues.
More or less, one path is Robinson Crusoe and the other, Barsoom.
But the key bit is that the game wouldn't judge you for your choices. The morality of the game would be of the colonial era, and butchering a bunch of Martians would all be framed as a triumph of the human will in a new age of discovery. There would be as much self-awareness here as there is in 20,000 Leagues when the crew of the Nautilus electrocutes a bunch of cannibals.
I'd like the choices to be less binary of course. Even if you decide to go native, you're still aligning yourself with one faction and acting out of a sense of moral objectivity. The question is just how much effort you're willing to put in to learn about this culture and how that knowledge will affect your actions.
